['Electricity - The flow or movement of electrons through a conductor, often harnessed as an energy source.', 'Energize - To provide energy or power to animate something or make it active and lively.', 'Electrode - A conductor in electric circuits used to make contact with a nonmetallic part of the circuit.', 'Electric car - An automobile that is propelled by an electrical motor rather than internal combustion.', 'Electron - A subatomic particle carrying a negative charge, fundamental to electricity and chemistry.', 'Electromagnetism - The branch of physics involving the study of electric charges at rest as well as in motion.', 'Electric current - The flow of electric charge through a conductor, typically measured in amperes.', 'Charge - In electrical terms, it refers to an entity that causes physical phenomena like attraction or repulsion.', 'Conductivity - A measure of the ability of a material to transfer energy (electricity) by means of moving electrons.', 'Circuit - A closed loop through which electric current flows.', 'Voltage - The potential difference in charge between two points, often measured in volts.', 'Capacitor - An electronic component that stores electrical energy and releases it when needed.', 'Insulator - Materials used to resist the flow of electrical current.', 'Transformer - A device that transfers electrical energy between two or more circuits through electromagnetic induction.', 'Power plant - Facility for the generation of electric power, often from a fuel source like coal, natural gas, hydroelectricity, nuclear reactions or solar power.', 'Electric field - The region around a charged particle where its influence is felt by other charges.', 'Resistor - An electrical component that restricts the flow of current to another point in an electric circuit.', 'Photovoltaic cell (solar cell) - A device that converts light into electricity using the photovoltaic effect.', 'Wattage - The rate at which energy is consumed or produced, typically measured in watts.', 'Electromagnetism - The study of the interaction between electrically charged particles and magnetic fields.']

['Cowl', 'Chaperon', 'Kukkula (historical Finnish term for monastic robe)', 'Tunic', 'Dalmatic (vestment worn by Roman Catholic priests and deacons over the alb, also used in monastic contexts)', "Rizinus (the part of a monks' hood that covers the face)", 'Hooded habit (clothing specific to religious orders like Benedictines or Trappists)', 'Chaperonier', 'Zucchetto (a small skullcap worn by Roman Catholic clergy, but sometimes used loosely in monastic contexts)', "Mantle (a type of outer cloak that may be part of a monk's attire)", 'Cassock (a long, close-fitting robe traditionally worn as the garment of Anglican and Roman Catholic clergy but also associated with some monastic orders)', 'Klobouk (a type of headdress that is part of Eastern Orthodox monastic attire)', 'Manto (historical term for a cloak-like robe worn by religious figures, including monks)', 'Zimarra (an elaborate ankle-length sleeved garment sometimes associated with theatrical or ceremonial purposes in certain traditions)', "Cappa (a liturgical cape that is part of some clergy's attire, which may resemble a monks' hood structure)", 'Phelonion (a liturgical vestment worn by bishops or priests in the Eastern Orthodox Church, but sometimes associated with certain monastic garments)', 'Mantle Cap (a headpiece that might be part of some religious garb and is reminiscent of a hooded cap)', 'Kappel (an old term for a type of clerical robe or cloak, occasionally used in monastic descriptions)', 'Pallium (a liturgical vestment worn by bishops in the Roman Catholic Church that has some similarities to hooded structures when worn over other garments)', "Zuccheto (an alternative spelling of zucchetto, mentioned earlier as it's not a widely recognized term globally)."]

['Desmodus - A genus of New World bat, known for their large size and strong teeth adapted to gnawing on wood.', 'Myotis - This group contains many species of bats often referred to as "mouse-eared" bats due to the shape of their ears; some are burrowers that feed on insects found underground.', "Vespertilio - A Latin name for bat, meaning 'evening star' – an old term used to describe creatures visible at dusk or in caves where they may roost.", 'Rhinolophinus - The Lesser Horseshoe Bat, a European species known for its unique snout that helps it locate insects underground; however, not all are considered burrowers.', 'Taphozous - This genus includes the Fruit Bats or Old World Fruit Bats whose large eyes and size can sometimes lead them to search in dark crevices including caves where they might roost but do not necessarily actively forage underground.', 'Nycteris - The Free-tailed Bat, known for its long tail membrane that aids in aerial maneuverability; some species are burrowers and may feed on insects found below the surface.', 'Pteropus - Known as flying foxes or fruit bats within this genus, they typically roost in trees but can sometimes be associated with caves where their activities might extend underground searching for food.', 'Chaerephon - A species of burrowing bat that inhabits Madagascar, feeding on termites and other subterranean insects using specialized snouts to detect them.', "Pizonyx - The Sokoke Pygmy Shrew Bat found in Africa; while not a true bat, its name suggests small size which could be associated with burrowers' family members.", 'Rhynchonycteris - Also known as the Key Largo Cotton-Grinder or Big Brown Bat, some species within this genus are insectivorous and might forage in underground spaces.', 'Furipterus - The Common Tapetum is a bat species found in South America; their diet often consists of insects that could be associated with subterranean environments.', 'Myzopoda - A genus containing the Malagasy Long-Tailed Bat, which may have ancestral traits linked to burrowing habits although not typical for modern bats.', 'Leptartiopicus - The Artibeus Bats are nectar feeders that sometimes enter caves or other shelters; some species might incidentally explore underground areas in search of food sources.', 'Nyctinomops - Generically called the Long-eared Bats, known for their long ears and adaptations to hunt moths at night which may include burrowing behaviors occasionally.', 'Tylonycteris - The Blossomsnout Bat; while primarily insectivorous and tree-roosting bats, some species might explore ground level areas for food.', 'Lonchophylla - A genus of South American nectarivorous bats that may occasionally engage in foraging behaviors associated with subterranean environments.', 'Cistothrix - The Neotropical Bats belonging to this group are generally insectivores; some species show a preference for searching in caves and crevices, potentially extending their search underground.', 'Glossophaga - Generally called the Greater Anteaters or Long-Tongued Bats; while not specifically burrowers, they can feed on nectar from flowers that might be found within subterranean ecosystems.']

CLUE: Did the Iliad log out these flowers?
OUTPUT: ['Hellenic (relating to ancient Greece, where the Iliad is set)', 'Trojan (related to the city-state in the epic)', "Poetic (describing a style of literature like that of Homer's Iliad)", 'Epic (a long narrative poem telling heroic deeds)', 'Odyssean (relating to Odysseus, who features prominently in the Iliad)', 'Herculean (describing a task requiring extraordinary strength or effort)', "Trojan War (the series of battles between Troy and Greek states that form the setting for Homer's epics)", 'Aeneid (a Latin epic poem by Virgil, indirectly connected to the Iliad through the broader context of classical literature)', 'Archaic (pertaining to an earlier period in history, which is when the Iliad was composed)', "Lyricism (the quality of being expressive and emotionally charged, as found in epic poetry like Homer's works)", 'Warrior (referring to heroes or characters depicted in the battle scenes of the Iliad)', 'Chorus (a group of narrators in Greek tragedy but conceptually akin to the collective voice in the epic poetry)', 'Mythology (the collection of myths that form the basis for many stories like those told in the Iliad)', 'Dactylic hexameter (the meter used by Homer in composing his epics, including the Iliad)', 'Trojans (referring to the inhabitants of Troy during the time depicted in the Iliad)', "Achilles' (pertaining to the Greek hero whose actions are central to many scenes in the Iliad)", 'Agamemnon (a king who plays a crucial role in both the Iliad and its companion, the Odyssey)', 'Nymphs (mythological spirits of nature which sometimes appear as characters in classical epics)']

['Aunt', 'Granny', 'Grandma', 'Nana', 'Oma', 'Godmother', 'Sister-in-law (if referring to a female relative who is married into the family)', "Cousin (female cousin's mother would be an example of this, although it may not always refer directly to the female relative herself)", "Auntie (an informal term for 'aunt')", 'Kinswoman', 'Kindred spirit (though less direct than some other options, can indicate a close bond like that between aunts and nieces/nephews)', "Godchild's mother (if referring to the mother of someone's goddaughter or godson)", 'Zonnie (a colloquial term for a younger sister in certain dialects, though not universally recognized as female relative)', "Auntie-in-law (referring specifically to one's husband/partner's aunt; again, more indirect than some other terms but still applicable under specific contexts)", 'Kinswoman (a formal term referring to any woman related by blood or marriage within the same family lineage)', "Godmother (similarly used for goddaughter's mother and can imply a relationship beyond mere biological ties in some cultural contexts)", 'Maiden (an archaic, poetic term sometimes referring to one’s unmarried female relative in literature or historical contexts)', "Sister-in-law (again, if considering the sister of one's spouse as a direct female relative through marriage)."]

['Vertebrae - The individual bones making up the backbone or spinal column in vertebrates.', "Spine - Another term for the backbone, referring to the entire series of interconnected bones and cartilage structures that form the central axis of an organism's skeleton.", 'Dorsal - Pertaining to the backside or posterior side, often used in relation to the backbone/spinal column.', "Atlas (C1 vertebra) - The first cervical vertebrae supporting the skull and connecting it to the spine; a crucial part of the backbone's structure.", 'Axis (C2 vertebra) - The second cervical vertebra, forming an axis for rotation of the head.', 'Thoracic Spine - The middle portion of the spinal column that connects to the rib cage and contains twelve thoracic vertebrae.', 'Lumbar Spine - The lower part of the backbone consisting of five lumbar vertebrae, responsible for providing support while allowing flexibility in movement.', 'Sacrum - A triangular bone located at the base of the spine between the two halves of the pelvis; an essential structure connecting the spinal column to the hip bones.', 'Coccyx (Tailbone) - The small, vestigial tail-like structure that comprises three or four fused coccygeal vertebrae at the base of the spine.', 'Intervertebral Disc - A fibrocartilaginous pad situated between adjacent vertebrae in the backbone; acts as a shock absorber and allows for flexibility during movement.', 'Vertebrate (Plural: vertebrates) - An organism with a vertebrate, or backbone/spinal column, comprised of one or more bony segments.', 'Spinal cord - The bundle of nerves extending from the brain through the spine; an essential part of the nervous system responsible for transmitting signals between the brain and the rest of the body.', "Sagittal Plane - A plane that divides the body or organism into left and right halves, which is often used to describe movement related to the backbone/spine' Written in reverse alphabetical order (Z-A):", 'Zygapophyseal Joints - The joints between adjacent vertebrae that provide stability and allow for controlled movements of the spinal column; also known as facet joints.', 'Yoke - In anatomy, a yoke is a structural feature found in some animals (especially birds), connecting segments of the spine or backbone together to distribute weight evenly.', 'X-ray - A medical imaging technique that uses electromagnetic radiation to create images of bone structures within the body, including the backbone/spinal column.', "Waters' View (Waters Projection) - An anatomical position used in radiology for obtaining a view of the skull and cervical spine on an X-ray image; patients are asked to tilt their head 30 degrees toward one side while keeping their chin up.", 'Upright Position (Standing) - A posture where an individual is standing, which affects the alignment of the backbone/spinal column and puts various stresses on it.', 'Vertebral Arch - The portion of a vertebra that encloses its spinal cord; consists of two pedicles, posterior elements (including processes), and an anterior arch.', 'Vestibular System - A sensory system located in the inner ear responsible for maintaining balance and spatial orientation; also involved in coordinating movements related to the backbone/spine during activities like walking or running.', 'Tendon Sheaths (Bandages) - Protective, tube-like structures that enclose tendons within the body; while not directly part of the backbone/spinal column, they play a role in maintaining proper alignment and reducing friction during movement.', "Torso - The main section of an organism's body between the neck (cervical region) and abdomen (abdominal region); includes the spine or backbone as one of its primary components, along with ribcage and pelvis.", 'Scoliosis - A medical condition characterized by a lateral curvature of the spine; affects the alignment and functioning of the backbone/spinal column.', 'Spinal Deformity - Any abnormality or malformation in the shape, position, or structure of the backbone/spine, which can lead to discomfort, pain, or limited mobility.', "Thoracic Cage (Ribcage) - The bony and cartilaginous framework that encloses and protects the thoracic cavity's vital organs; while not directly part of the backbone/spinal column, it is closely related to its function and structure.", 'Spondylolisthesis - A condition where one vertebra slides forward over the one below it due to a fracture or dislocation within the spine; affects the alignment and stability of the backbone/spinal column.', 'Spinous Processes - The bony projections that extend posteriorly from each individual vertebra in the spine, serving as points of attachment for muscles and ligaments while also providing protection to the spinal cord.']
